If you want to prove that something is true for all functions f₁ with that specific property, having it as a hypothesis to those lemmas is the right way to go about it
you can do that either by including the hypothesis explicitly in the statements of those lemmas, or by declaring it as a variable like Andrew Yang suggested

hf₁ works, but why ↑and what does it mean here?

My following lemma yields the error messages below.

import Mathlib
variable {X : Type*} {X₁ D Y : Set X} (f₁ : D → Y) (hf₁ : ∀ x : D, ↑x ∈ X₁ → ↑(f₁ x) ∈ X₁)
lemma Lemma0b (h1 : ∀ x : D, ↑(f₁ x) ∉ X₁) : x ∉ X₁ := by
  intro negation_of_assertion

h1 x

but is expected to have type
↑D : Type u_1

What is wrong here?

hf1 expects a first argument of type D. You did not introduce x but Lean guessed that it was of type X, which is the wrong type. You can disable this behaviour by writing set_option autoImplicit false after the import.

Are you sure you want to manipulate functions from subtypes of X? You wrote f:D⊇X→Y⊆Xf : D \supseteq X \to Y \subseteq Xf:D⊇X→Y⊆X, and maybe you are used to having partially defined functions in paper maths with set theory, but in Lean things would be nicer with f:X→Xf : X \to Xf:X→X and dealing with subsets.

To answer your question about ↑: it stands for a coercion, and here comes from the fact that D is technically a term of type Set X, not a type itself. When you talk about it in contexts where lean expects a type, like in x : D or f₁ : D → Y, lean automatically coerces it to a type. In the background this happens via docs#Set.Elem, but to make things more readable you see it pretty-printed as just ↑D.

Specifically, writing h1 : ∀ x : D, ... means that h1 takes in terms of type ↑D, and giving it anything else results in the error you have just seen. When you have some x : X you can only apply h1 to it by first constructing a term of type ↑D from x and proof that x ∈ D; this is basically what my earlier comment about f ⟨x, hx⟩ was about. But you don't even have x : X here, since like Etienne said, you didn't introduce x as a variable and lean just tried to guess what you could have meant

Also note that there is a technical difference between ∀ x : D and ∀ x ∈ D: the former expects a term of type ↑D, while the latter is a special notation just for sets and expects terms x : X and hx : x ∈ D directly. In contexts like this that makes it usually slightly nicer to use

This works for what you're trying to to:

import Mathlib

variable {X : Type*} {X₁ D Y : Set X} (f₁ : D → Y) (hf₁ : ∀ x : D, ↑x ∈ X₁ → ↑(f₁ x) ∈ X₁)

include hf₁

lemma Lemma0b  (h1 : ∀ x : D, ↑(f₁ x) ∉ X₁) (x : D) : ↑x ∉ X₁ := by
  intro negation_of_assertion
  exact h1 x (hf₁ x negation_of_assertion)

but I'm also not quite sure that you're doing yourself a favour by working with subsets of a type instead of plain types here.

I wrote and meant: f1 ⁣:X⊇D→Y⊆Xf_1\colon X\supseteq D\to Y\subseteq Xf1​:X⊇D→Y⊆X. I haven't defined the functions f1f_1f1​ partially.

I want to translate my mathematical formulations into Lean as accurately as possible.
Why should I not use subsets for domains and ranges of functions and relations even though I need them?

I don't know what you are trying to achieve so I can't tell with absolute certainty that you should take f:X→Xf : X \to Xf:X→X rather than defining it only on subsets, but in most cases you can get a formulation which is equivalent without troubling you with it. Anyway here is a way of formulating and proving your statement without subtypes, it avoids coercions so it's nicer:

import Mathlib

variable {X : Type*} {X₁ D Y : Set X} (f₁ : X → X) (hf₁ : ∀ x ∈ D ∩ X₁, f₁ x ∈ Y ∩ X₁)

include hf₁

lemma Lemma0b (h1 : ∀ x ∈ D, f₁ x ∉ X₁) (x : X) (hx : x ∈ D) : x ∉ X₁ := by
  intro negation_of_assertion
  have : x ∈ D ∩ X₁ := Set.mem_inter hx negation_of_assertion
  have : f₁ x ∈ Y ∩ X₁ := hf₁ x this
  have : f₁ x ∈ X₁ := Set.mem_of_mem_inter_right this
  exact h1 x hx this

Ben Eltschig said:

To answer your question about ↑: it stands for a coercion, and here comes from the fact that D is technically a term of type Set X, not a type itself. When you talk about it in contexts where lean expects a type, like in x : D or f₁ : D → Y, lean automatically coerces it to a type. In the background this happens via docs#Set.Elem, but to make things more readable you see it pretty-printed as just ↑D.

I told you here already. Functions are defined between types, but D and Y are terms of type Set X, not types, so some coercion to a type needs to happen first. The arrow simply is the visual representation of that, and when you hover over it you can see exactly what coercion it represents - there's nothing unclear or ambiguous about it.

It's just a technicality coming from the fact that a subset of a type and the type of its elements are slightly different things in lean, even though when doing math we like to think of them as one and the same. A similar thing also happens with for example natural and real numbers - if you have some n : ℕ and a function f : ℝ → ℝ, writing f n and then inspecting the term will get you f ↑n. That's not because f n was somehow unclear or lean misunderstood it, but simply because n is technically not a real number already and so needs to be coerced to one first. Lean knows this, automatically inserts the coercion and displays it as an arrow to let you see it's there.

a set (e.g. C\mathbb{C}C)

In Lean, C\mathbb{C}C is not a set. It's a type. Of course, you could get a set of all of the complex numbers with (Set.univ : Set ℂ), but it's not clear why you would want to do that.

Keep in mind that a lot of things that are normally conceptualized as sets are better represented as types in Lean. When we define functions, we define them between types, not sets. (I know Ben just said this but it's worth repeating.) Even when it looks like we're writing a function between sets, it's actually a function between the types of members of those sets.
